abstract.text: The present paper highlights the data analysis status of the OPERA experiment.

The experiment was designed to perform the neutrino interactions analysis on event-by-event basis, and optimized to search for νµ → ντ oscillation in appearance mode, also allowing to perform a νe appearance search.
We review the data simulation and the analysis chains implemented to search for ντ interactions.

The main kinematical parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor are discussed, the uncertainties of the event parameter estimation are reviewed, and the main sources of background for the νµ → ντ oscillation search are examined.
The topologies of the two first ντ candidate events are presented.
Finally, we review the status of the νe appearance search and present the constraints set by the OPERA experiment on the mixing angle θ 13 and on the LSND/MiniBooNE anomaly.

body_text.text: Introduction
An idea of neutrino oscillations was introduced by B.M. Pontecorvo long ago.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 1 However, it took over 40 years to get the first definite experimental result in favor of oscillations.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 2 Now it is firmly established that the number of the "active" neutrino flavors amounts to 3 (formal fit gives 2.998±0.008 3 ), thus oscillations between these states are described by 3×3 Pontecorvo-Maki-Nakagawa-Sakata (PMNS) matrix.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 4 Further experiments with solar, 5 atmospheric, 6,7 reactor 8 and accelerator 9-11 neutrinos gave additional support to the oscillation hypothesis.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Recently the value of the last previously unknown mixing angle θ 13 was measured in the Daya Bay experiment.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 12 Some phenomenological models introduce and some experiments (e.g. 13,14 ) support the existence of m additional ("sterile") neutrino states that may participate in oscillations; in that case the PMNS matrix is 3 + m-dimensional.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Other unsolved problems, besides the question of sterile neutrinos existence, are those of neutrino mass hierarchy and of CP violation in the leptonic sector.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The decisive proof of ν τ appearance in ν µ → ν τ oscillation is also still absent; only recently the Super-Kamiokande experiment found the evidence for this effect.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 15 The OPERA experiment was designed to search for ν µ → ν τ oscillation on eventby-event basis by observing τ decays.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: OPERA might be also handy in constraining the active-sterile neutrino mixing parameters, and the so-called non-standard interaction (NSI) parameters, 16 that may give rise to ν τ component in the initially pure ν µ beam.

body_text.text: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

OPERA is a very complex hybrid detector that consists of electronic and emulsion detectors that are able to sample the event development on highly different spatial scales, starting from L ≈ 20 m -the lenght of the full detector -to submicron level needed to sucessfully identify the ν τ events.
body_text.section: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

body_text.text: OPERA DAQ 20 has a high efficiency of response to neutrino interactions contained in the detector volume (according to, 21 more than 95 %).
body_text.section: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

body_text.text: However, most of ν τ signal gets lost at the further stages of the event reconstruction and analysis, and the final ν τ finding efficiency is about 6-8 %.
body_text.section: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

body_text.text: The main steps of the standard OPERA event analysis chain are:
body_text.section: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

body_text.text: (1) Selection of contained events that have the interaction (primary) vertex inside the OPERA volume.
body_text.section: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

body_text.text: 22 (2) Search for the element of the emulsion detector -the so-called brick -that contains the primary vertex (brick finding (BF) procedure) 23 (3) Each brick contains additional attached emulsion layers (the changeable sheets or CS) needed to confirm the presence of charged particle tracks crossing the brick.
body_text.section: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

body_text.text: The CS are searched for converging patterns or tracks that have an angle close to the reconstructed one from the electronic detector (ED) information 24 (see also 17 ).
body_text.section: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

body_text.text: In case of the positive signal the corresponding brick is analyzed.
body_text.section: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

body_text.text: (4) Vertex location inside the brick and the event topology reconstruction.
body_text.section: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

body_text.text: (5) Then follows the decay search (DS) procedure needed to search for the signature of the short-lived τ decay to identify ν τ charged current (CC) interactions.
body_text.section: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

body_text.text: 25 (6) After reconstruction of the event kinematical parameters, the kinematical selection is applied in order to further supress the background.
body_text.section: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

body_text.text: Relevant efficiencies on the different stages of analysis are defined in 26 and revised in; 27 their up-to date values are discussed in.
body_text.section: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

body_text.text: 17 Most efficiencies were estimated with dedicated MC simulations.
body_text.section: The sketch of the OPERA simulation/analysis chain

body_text.text: The detector response simulation was performed using the recently introduced software framework OpRelease.

body_text.text: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment
Due to the excellent spatial resolution of the OPERA detector, usually a wealth of information about the event is available.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: Here we list the main parameters that are sensitive to the primary neutrino flavor, thus making it possible to perform a ν τ search.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: Let us remark that the dominating background for ν τ observation is charm production in ν µ -CC interactions (see sec. 5 for more details).
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: (1) The presence of muon or electron in the primary vertex allows to exclude the ν τ hypothesis in favor of the ν µ -CC or ν e -CC interaction hypothesis, respectively.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: Muons are usually clearly seen by the ED as long penetrating tracks (efficiency of muon ID with OPERA ED is ≈95 %).
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: 21 In especially interesting events it is possible to follow down the tracks in other emulsion bricks to refine the muon search.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: (2) Even in the case when the muon or electron in the primary vertex was missed, efficient selection of ν τ is still possible.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: It appears that the azimuthal angle φ between the τ candidate and hadronic jet is a powerful background-supressing variable, as the charmed hadron tends to follow the direction of the primary hadronic jet closely (it is just a part of the jet).
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: On the contrary, transverse momentum conservation enforces the most of leptons (µ in ν µ -CC events and τ in ν τ -CC events) to have φ values > π/2.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: In practice, the two slightly amended versions of the φ variable definition are usable.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: (a) The so-called "exclusive" φ E .
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: In events with > 1 particles in the primary jet the track that has the largest φ is removed and the φ parameter calculation is repeated to get the φ E value.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: This exclusion procedure is intended to remove not-identified µ while calculating the φ E value.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: (b) Even more sophisticated version of the φ parameter is the-so-called "modified" φ mod .
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: In this case the largest φ track is excluded unless it is identified as a hadron, which allows to avoid excluding of a genuine hadron from the φ mod calculation.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: The φ mod distributions for the τ → h (1h) and τ → 3h (3h) decay channels are shown in 17 ( fig. 12).
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: (3) For the τ → µ decay channel: If charge sign of µ from the secondary vertex is negative, then the charm background is greatly reduced.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: (4) For the τ → 3h decay channel: τ decays into charged particles and neutrinos due to lepton charge conservation, while charm decay may be neutrinoless.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: This affects the kinematical parameters from the secondary (decay) vertex, especially the transverse momentum, and allows to select a part of ν τ events.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: (5) Other parameters (slope of the τ candidate track with respect to the primary beam direction, total momentum of the charged "daughters", 3D angle between the primary jet and the τ candidate, etc...) are also sensitive to the neutrino flavor.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: It is possible to introduce multidimensional method of ν τ search.
body_text.section: Parameters sensitive to the neutrino flavor in the OPERA experiment

body_text.text: This method is currently under study; it might allow to relax the kinematical cuts and ensure more effective rejection of background, thus enhancing the statistical significance of the ν τ observation.

body_text.text: The event parameters estimation with the OPERA emulsion detector
The most of useful kinematical information in OPERA comes from emulsion brick analysis.
body_text.section: The event parameters estimation with the OPERA emulsion detector

body_text.text: The two systems for emulsion data analysis are available: SYSAL (System of Salerno) 28 and FEDRA (Framework for Emulsion Data Reconstruction and Analysis).
body_text.section: The event parameters estimation with the OPERA emulsion detector

body_text.text: 29 A well known fact is that the emulsion contains numerous grains of "fog", 30 thus one needes to establish additional selection criteria to supress the background while linking the short fragments of the tracks in single emulsion layer -the so-called microtracks.
body_text.section: The event parameters estimation with the OPERA emulsion detector

body_text.text: The main linking criteria demand that the microtracks must have good angular coincidence and the distance between straight lines that contain the microtracks is small.
body_text.section: The event parameters estimation with the OPERA emulsion detector

body_text.text: It appears that a part of the tracks from low-energy particles exhibits strong scattering in lead interleaved between the emulsion layers, and thus these tracks are not reconstructed.
body_text.section: The event parameters estimation with the OPERA emulsion detector

body_text.text: The microtrack linking efficiency for electrons vs. energy was calculated in 31 and shown in fig. 1 (black curve).
body_text.section: The event parameters estimation with the OPERA emulsion detector

body_text.text: Additional studies with the only cut on the angle between the microtracks were performed 32 using the Geant4 package; 33 their results are shown in fig. 1 by blue (50 mrad cut) and red (150 mrad cut) lines with the statistical uncertainties.
body_text.section: The event parameters estimation with the OPERA emulsion detector

body_text.text: Let us remark that the most of hadron tracks are assumed to be reconstructed starting from the minimal momentum of 100-300 M eV /c or even lower.
body_text.section: The event parameters estimation with the OPERA emulsion detector

body_text.text: After the event topology reconstruction one can estimate the particle parameters from emulsion data.
body_text.section: The event parameters estimation with the OPERA emulsion detector

body_text.text: Background for ν τ observation
Prompt ν τ background is negligible, according to, 38 where actually calculations for the CHORUS experiment were done.
body_text.section: Background for ν τ observation

body_text.text: The CHORUS beam parameters are comparable with the CNGS parameters.
body_text.section: Background for ν τ observation

body_text.text: The main sources of background for oscillated ν τ observation are as follows: (1) Background from ν µ -CC events with charm production.
body_text.section: Background for ν τ observation

body_text.text: The events with charmed hadron and low-energy muon with large angle (>1 rad) w.r.t. the axis of the neutrino beam constitute a very dangerous background.
body_text.section: Background for ν τ observation

body_text.text: In order to reduce this kind of background, the new methods for large-angle scanning were recently introduced.
body_text.section: Background for ν τ observation

body_text.text: These methods allow to raise the angular acceptance of scanning microscopes from 0.6-0.8 rad to nearly 1.2-1.3 rad.
body_text.section: Background for ν τ observation

body_text.text: (2) Extensive studies of background from inelastic hadron and muon interactions also were performed (see 17,19 for more details).

body_text.text: Conclusions
We have reviewed the present status of the OPERA experiment aimed on eventby-event ν µ → ν τ oscillation search in appearance mode.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Three ν τ candidates were observed so far.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The main sources of background were carefully studied.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The complete simulation/analysis framework OpRelease was recently established, allowing to perform more realistic MC studies.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Constraints on θ 13 and the LSND/MiniBooNE anomaly were set profiting of the excellent particle identification capabilities of the OPERA detector.
